tn.text: Paul speaks to the Jewish crowd in Jerusalem.
Verse 2 gives background information. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_background]])
This is a polite way of addressing men who are Paul's age as well as the older men in the audience.

tn.ref: I will now make to you
tn.text: "I will now explain to you" or "I will now present to you"
The Hebrew language was the language of the Jews.

tn.ref: but educated in this city at the feet of Gamaliel
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "but I was a student of rabbi Gamaliel here in Jerusalem" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
Here "feet" stands for the place where a student would sit while learning from a teacher. AT: "by Gamaliel" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Gamaliel was one of the most prominent teachers of the Jewish law. See how you translated this name in [[:en:bible:notes:act:05:33|5:34]].

tn.ref: I was instructed according to the strict ways of the law of our forefathers
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "He instructed me how to carefully obey every law of our forefathers" or "The instruction I received followed the exact details of the law of our forefathers" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
This is another way of saying "law of Moses."
"I am completely dedicated to obeying God" or "I am passionate about my service to God"

tn.ref: just as all of you are today
tn.text: "in the same way all of you are today." Paul compares himself with the crowd.
This was a term used to refer to Christianity. See how you translated "the Way" in [[:en:bible:notes:act:09:01|9:2]].

The word "death" can be translated with the verb "kill" or "die."  AT: "and I looked for ways to kill them" (UDB)" or "and I even caused them to die" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
"threw them into prison" or put them into prison"
"tell how," "attest that," or "testify that"
"The high priests and elders gave me letters"
Here "brothers" refers to "fellow Jews."

tn.ref: I was to bring back in bonds to Jerusalem those of this Way
tn.text: "They ordered me to bind with chains those of the Way and bring them back to Jerusalem"
This can be stated in active form. AT: "in order that they may receive punishment" or "in order that the Jewish authorities could punish them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
Paul describes his encounter with Jesus.
This phrase is used here to mark where the action starts. If your language has a way for doing this, you could consider using it here.

tn.ref: heard a voice say to me
tn.text: Here "voice" stands for the person speaking. AT: "I heard someone say to me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

tn.ref: they did not understand the voice of him who spoke to me
tn.text: Here "voice" stands for the person speaking. AT: "they did not understand what the one who spoke to me was saying" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
This can be stated in active form. AT: "there someone will tell you" or "there you will find out" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: I could not see because of that light's brightness
tn.text: "I was left blind because of that light's brightness"

tn.ref: I went into Damascus being led by the hands of those who were with me
tn.text: Here "hands" stands for those leading Paul. This can be stated in active form. AT: "those with me guided me into Damascus" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
The words "He" and "him" refer to Ananias.

Though this is not the same Ananias who died earlier in Acts [[:en:bible:notes:act:05:03|5:3]], you may translate it the same way though as you did in [[:en:bible:notes:act:05:01|5:1]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: devout man according to the law
tn.text: Ananias was very serious about following God's law.

tn.ref: well spoken of by all the Jews who lived there
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "the Jews who lived there spoke well of him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
Here "Brother" is a polite way to address someone. AT: "My friend Saul" (UDB)
The word"sight" can be translated with the verb "see." AT: "see again" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
This was a customary way of saying something happened immediately. AT: "At that instant," "Instantly," "Right away" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
Paul finishes telling what had happened to him in Damascus. He quotes what Ananias said to him. This is still part of his speech to the crowd in Jerusalem.
The word "he" refers to Ananias. (See: [[:en:bible:notes:act:22:12|22:12]])
"what God is planning and will cause to happen"

tn.ref: to hear the voice coming from his own mouth
tn.text: Both "voice" and "mouth" refer to the one speaking. AT: "to hear him speak directly to you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
Here "men" means all people whether male or female. AT: "to all people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_gendernotations]])
Here "now" does not mean "at this moment," but is used to draw attention to the important point that follows.
This question was asked to exhort Paul to be baptized. AT: "Do not wait!" or "Do not delay!" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
This can be stated in active form. AT: "let me baptize you" (UDB) or "receive baptism" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

As washing one's body removes dirt, calling on the name of Jesus for forgiveness cleanses one's inner being from sin. AT: "ask forgiveness for your sins" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Here "name" refers to the Lord. AT: "calling on the Lord" or "trusting in the Lord"
Paul begins to tell the crowd about his vision of Jesus.
This phrase is used here to mark where the action starts. If your language has a way for doing this, you could consider using it here.
This can be stated in active form. AT: "I had a vision" or "God gave me a vision" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: I saw him say to me
tn.text: "I saw Jesus as he said to me"

tn.ref: they will not accept your testimony about me
tn.text: "those who live in Jerusalem will not believe what you tell them about me"
This ends what Paul was able to say to the crowd of Jewish people by the fortress.
Here the word "they" refers to the non-believing Jews in Jerusalem.
The word "themselves" is used for emphasis. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_rpronouns]])
Paul went to synagogues to find Jews who believed in Jesus.

tn.ref: the blood of Stephen your witness was spilled
tn.text: Here "blood" stands for Stephen's life. To spill blood means to kill. This can be stated in active form. AT: "they killed Stephen who testified about you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
Here the words "him" and the first two words "he" refer to Paul. The word "He" and the last "he" refer to the chief captain.

tn.ref: Away with such a fellow from the earth
tn.text: The phrase "from the earth" adds emphasis to "Away with such a fellow." AT: "Kill him"
"While they were" (UDB). The phrase "As they were" is used to mark two events that are happening at the same time.

tn.ref: throwing off their cloaks, and throwing dust into the air
tn.text: These actions show that the Jews there are outraged because they feel Paul has spoken against God. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction]])
a Roman military officer or leader of about 600 soldiers
This can be stated in active form. AT: "ordered his soldiers to bring Paul" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
This fortress was connected to the outer temple court. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:act:21:34|21:34]].

tn.ref: He ordered that he should be questioned with scourging
tn.text: The commander wants Paul tortured by whipping him to ensure he tells the truth. This can be stated in active form. AT: "He ordered his soldiers to whip Paul to force him to tell the truth" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
The word "himself" is used for emphasis. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_rpronouns]])
Here the word "they" refers to the soldiers.
These were strips of leather or animal hide.

tn.ref: Is it lawful for you to scourge a man who is a Roman and uncondemned?
tn.text: Paul uses this question to make the centurion check the validity of having his soldiers whip Paul. AT: "It is not lawful for you to whip a man who is a Roman and not condemned!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion|Rhetorical Question]])
This means no one has proven him guilty in court.

tn.ref: What are you about to do?
tn.text: This question is used to urge the commander to reconsider his plan to whip Paul. AT: "You should not do this!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion|Rhetorical Question]])
Here the word "him" refers to Paul.
Here "came" can be translated as "went." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_go]])

tn.ref: It was only with a large amount of money
tn.text: "It was only after I paid a lot of money to the Roman authorities." The captain makes this statement because he knows how hard it is to become a Roman citizen, and he suspects Paul is not telling truth.
"I obtained citizenship" or "I became a citizen"

tn.ref: I was born a Roman citizen
tn.text: If the father is a Roman citizen, then his children become Roman citizens automatically when they are born.

tn.ref: the men who were going to question
tn.text: "the men who planned to question" or "the men who were preparing to question"
Here the word "he" refers to the chief captain.
a military officer of about 600 soldiers
Possibly the "chief officer" stands for the chief officers' soldiers. AT: "So the chief captain ordered his soldiers to untie Paul's bonds" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
From the fortress, there is a stairway going down to the temple courts.
